reviewText: It's kind of interesting. I remember when "The English Patient" came out it won a ton of awards and everyone loved it. It certainly had some of the problems that people claim this movie had - bombastic, over-the-top, melodramatic, with plenty of over-acting (Ralph Fiennes, as good as he is, is often guilty of that in spades). Yet that movie receives a lot of praise (it had a higher budget, but still) and this movie gets negative reviews.I really liked this movie. Not because it seeks to reorder our preconceived notions of cinematic narrative, or any such lofty, ambitious, goal, but because it's a throwback to the old days of larger-than-life, chewy 1940s escapist epics.Which is not to say it's the period piece equivalent of "Dude, Where's My Car?" The movie does have subtlety, very good acting, well-written characters, some beautiful shots and camera work (I'm not talking about outside Gilda's Paris apartment either), and some good messages. It also has all the requisites of a good epic to - a large, sweeping feel; love, loss, and death; great locations and scenery, grandoise, dramatic events in world history contrasted with changes in the lives of individuals, and so on.It totally succeeds on its merits. It's not trying to win an Oscar, it's meant to be an entertaining World War 2 epic, and for me, it most certainly is. For me, the strength of this movie is the acting by the three leads and the sharply written characters. I really liked this characters and cared about what happened to them, and thought Townsend, Cruz, and Theron did a great job making me care about them. Cruz and her character were particularly irresistible. Townsend's acting isn't inferior, he's simply given less to work with. Theron brings more humanity and makes a somewhat stock character (the libertine socialite in these type of movies is a fixture) less irritating than usual and gives her more twists.This movie is full of nice little touches. For example, when Cruz's character Mia is working as a nurse on the battle front in Spain, her face appears to be marked by a rash. Realistic for the time in unsanitary and exhausting conditions, and quite a contrast to the unrealistically glamorously made-up Nicole Kidman in the Civil War era movie Cold Mountain (she looks like she just stepped off a fashion runway).In conclusion, if you like period piece epics, this is definitely one to see.
summary: An epic period piece propelled by good acting that I really enjoyed.

reviewText: This period piece seems to run on forever. The characters establish themselves well enough but there is no compelling story to grab our attention. The sets also had a fake look to them - I don't think this was filmed on location. It felt like I was watching a stage rendition of Paris - it's hard to figure out what's wrong but the whole hting looks fake and not very well done.

History is not kind to these lovers, for though they share a bond with one another, there's Hitler's horrible war just outside their door and each one must review their convictions and loyalty to each other, and themselves.There's a very erotic strip-tease scene with Cruz, as well as other sexually charged scenes, so be sure only 'mature' audiences are watching. It was wonderful to see Theron and Cruz in a movie together and the actresses complement one another's talents very well.Chrissy K. McVay - Author

reviewText: I watched this movie on the recommendation of a friend.  I'm now reconsidering our friendship.  This movie begins with an improbable event (shy college student has his studies interrupted by beautiful woman seeking overnight shelter in his room), and it goes downhill from there.  Although Roger Ebert disagrees, I think Charlize Theron was terribly miscast as the heroine (?), Gilda.  Despite her Oscar win, I don't think she has the acting chops to carry off this kind of role.  She's not bad when the script requires "bouncy," but as the going gets rougher, her performance becomes pretty much one-note.  Stuart Townshend is as boring as they come.  There is not one point in the film where he stands out.  The surprise for me was Penelope Cruz.  She should have been onscreen longer.Also, if one watches the "making of" featurette, you'll see why the street scenes look unreal:  They're fake!  The background is a blue screen.By the way, I'm still not sure exactly whose head was in the clouds.  Maybe it was the screenwriter's.
summary: Life Is Precious... Don't Waste Any Of Yours On This

reviewText: Most menage-a-trois films are erotic thrillers that most certainly have nothing to do with war.  So, this film breaks some new ground there.  Of course, typically this WOULD have been a fairly happy go lucky movie.  I mean, it's a pretty lucky fellow to enjoy the company of two beautiful women (played by Charlize Theron & Penelope Cruz).  Unfortunately, war tends to interfere with all our plans.One of the best features of this movie is that it details the Spainish civil war.  To most people this is a forgotten conflict.  Outside of its depiction in Ernest Hemingway's FOR WHOM THE BELL TOLLS, most Americans don't know anything about it.If you're looking for a movie that can be described as both a chick-flick as well as a war movie, this one just might be for you.  Yes, it also includes every man's fantasy as well, but goes way beyond that.  While some aspects of it seem a bit incomplete, this is nonetheless a great film.
summary: A differnt brand of war movie

reviewText: I would actually give this film 3.5 stars.  It has a great start, a great cast, beautiful cinematography but it is passionless.  This is a story about three young lovers who live life at its best when there is war all around.  When two of them decide to take the Spanish Civil War seriously and volunteer themselves, one refuses to change her exuberant lifestyle despite what's going on around her.The story is great and the characters are convincing yet there is still the passion missing among all three characters.  They are supposed to be bound by their zest for life. And there is a lot of talk about how much they love each other.  Yet, I expected more intimate moments between Stuart Townsend's character and Charlize Theron's character.  There was more passion between Diego and Frida in Salma Hayek's film about Frida Kahlo that took place around the same timeframe.The movie has great potential and definitely worth a watch, but Theron does not quite deliver the oscar winning performace here as she did with "Monster". Had the film left out Penelope Cruz, I think this could have been a better film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I am not a fan of this type of filmmaking in this era.  What does happen here, however, is a trio of very skilled, very talented and very beautiful actors are corralled into what John Duigan's imagination sees as a Big 40's Hollywood Epic.  Everyone gets a chance to spread their wings and look marvelous in vintage costumes.  Everyone gets to emote on a GRAND SCALE.  Everyone gets to have an epiphany which changes their lives.The entire proceeding feels a bit contrived (well, more than a bit, actually) but is not without merit, even if it isn't  entirely successful in fully conveying its epic aspiration.With its mix of high style, tortured romance, war, friendship, loyalty and heartbreak one cannot help but be reminded of The English Patient or Farewell to Arms or any number of other epic flicks combining war and romance but "Clouds" doesn't have that real snap and sweep of an epic.  Still everyone looks great and the story is engaging enough.  If you're like me, you'll feel bad that the film didn't live up to its potential and you'll want to like it more than you actually do.
summary: Epic Wannabe Falls Short of Mark.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Writer and Director John Duigan has added to his cinematic stature with this recent film about the interrelated responses of three countries - England, France, Spain - to the early phases of WW II and in doing so gives some inadveryent insight into how the continent was so endangered by the little known bad boy Hitler in the years leading up to the horror of a second World War.The title seems very appropriate - taken from the quip of 'Head in the clouds, Feet on the ground' - as the lead character Gilda (a radiantly beautiful Charlize Theron) seems to float above all of the reality of warring struggles in 1933, focusing her life on paramours, expensive clothes, and 'dangerous liaisons' with a varied assortment of men, all the while keeping a firm stance on needs of her strangely disjointed life.  Indeed, the opening of the film finds Gilda in need of shelter from a night's fling with a Cambridge lover and she knocks on the door of a poor struggling Irish student Guy (Stuart Townsend), thus beginning a lasting affair that coasts through the entire story.Guy eventually follows Gilda to Paris where she is a popular photographer living with her gallerist, but also living with her lesbian lover Mia (Penelope Cruz).  Gilda, Guy, and Mia become a triptych and it is only the impact of the rise of fascism in Spain (Mia's home) that separates the ménage a trois: idealistic Guy and compassionate Mia are off to fight Franco while Gilda is left behind to admit to the encroaching threat of Nazis in France and enter into her own version of involvement.How these three weather the war and resolve their varied degrees of complicity provides the film's finale.  The cast is strong, the settings are gorgeous (in all three countries) as captured by cinematographer Paul Sarossy, and the musical score by Terry Frewer introduces a potential talent for film composition (while borrowing heavily from French cabaret songs, symphonic music by Edward Elgar, and pieces of Francis Poulenc).  But the overall reason for enjoying this rather long film is the interplay of Theron, Townsend and Cruz in a variety of richly sensuous vignettes. Well worth watching. Grady Harp, January 2005
summary: World War II from the European View

reviewText: Paris, the always shining beacon of the world, is the frame of this interesting and painful portrait around the lives and times of three outlaw human beings: the most liberal of all of them, the authentic center of gravity of manners, tastes and behavior: Charlize Theron plays Gilda, the irreverence made woman, who has given shelter to a nurse - Penelope Cruz - and has allowed her to go ahead with her bliss and dreams. Both of them lives the convulsed and fabulous thirties, where the Charleston and jazz sounds were emerging with particular emphasis. Her brief stage in Cambridge, allows her to meet a very special man, who eventually will become the love of her life.This unlimited happiness will be interrupted by the war, attending the call of the conscious, curiously. She as a nurse and he, as sensible human being feel that their happy state of life is not in harmony with a bleeding world; in the neighbor country Spain: The Civil War is a very hard reality to ignore it. That fact will break this curious triangle and both of them will become protagonists of this drama.Charlize is absolutely devastated in this sense, but this emotional crossroad, this existential dilemma will transform her, leaving behind all the selfishness and she will do her best, according her possibilities to contribute the cause against the world of shadows.A convincing script with certain narrative pauses, but with enough rhythmic pulse to arrive to a crude but satisfactory conclusion. Charlize Theron was marvelous and credible. Her kaleidoscopic beauty allows her to combine several behaviors: as femme fatale, alluring lover and elusively enigmatic character.Filmed with a visible inspirational European flavor, that reminded me to Claude Sautet.
summary: Three nationalities, three twists of fate!

reviewText: "Head in the Clouds" is a historical romance/drama, which takes place in Europe before and during WWII. Although it covers an extremely fascinating period in terms of world events, this thoroughly disagreeable film takes little advantage of the many interesting storyline possibilities that history offers. What I'd like to know is, whatever possessed director/screenwriter John Duigan to turn beautiful, gifted Charlize Theron into a grotesque caricature of herself. And how did he do it? Was he using voodoo? Sally Bowles she most definitely is not! (although Liza Minnelli gave a stellar performance in that role). There are even scenes where the incomparable Penelope Cruz looks preposterous, as the uncomfortable third wheel in a menage-a-threesome.Ms. Theron plays Gilda Besse, the narcissistic playgirl daughter of a wealthy American socialite, (a suicide), and a French champagne tycoon, who is somewhat mad. She warns a lover, who fantasizes about a possible future with her, along with their potential children, "I have doomed genes!" Gilda has worked as a photographer, a dancer and an actress in a Hollywood movie, but mostly she dabbles. She always appears to be vamping for a camera lens, even when there is no apparent camera. Her wardrobe is simply gorgeous though. Probably the best part of the movie is watching the innumerable costume changes - usually one per scene, but we get two-for-one when Penelope Cruz is around to model. Another high point is cinematographer Paul Sarossy's wonderful footage of Paris. The movie is almost worth renting just to look at the Paris cityscapes.Anyway, before Gilda went to live in gay Paree, where she was to lose any vestige of freshness she may still have had at age 23, she was in England - Cambridge to be exact. One night, she wandered tipsily into the university dormitory room of Guy Malyon, (Stuart Townsend). He is a Dublin-born student on scholarship, and the son of an Irish policeman. In real life, Townsend and Charlize are a couple, and I am sure they make a charming twosome. However, in this movie, there is zilch chemistry between them. He is a handsome, sincere, if somewhat naive young man, but certainly not mature or edgy enough for Gilda, who eats men alive. She is too busy posing to stir up much heat with anyone, anyway. Guy and Gilda meet, once again, at an extremely wild party on a country estate. They are intimate on a billiard table, and then Gilda bids him adieu. She is off to see the world. In one of her parting lines, she mentions Arabia. Hah!! Meanwhile, Guy become a teacher and social activist as fascism looms over Europe.Years pass and Guy cannot forget Gilda. The very thought of her sends his hormones off the charts. So when she contacts him once more and asks him to visit her in Paris - he's off in a flash to the City of Lights! He finds her with a variety of meaningless lovers, working at "photography as art." She remains unattainable, even as he holds her. I think Gilda is supposed to come across as carefree - but she is too studied and jaded to be the free-spirit type. The lovely Spanish Mia, (Cruz), was an exotic dancer until Miss Besse brought her home to stay. She now lives with Gilda and Gilda's current man-of-the-moment.Politics and war finally overtake Europe and ruin Gilda's plans, especially when both Guy and Mia depart to fight for Republican Spain. She is furious that the two are leaving. "There will always be wars," she tells them, "you need to get rid of the guilt." To say anything more would be to spoil what plot there is. One gets the feel that because Gilda, as a teen, had her fortune told, and it wasn't a good one, she believes life is preordained. All is fate. Therefore she lives as much and as fast as she can before karma can overtake her.This is one of the rare occasions that I write, without qualification, don't bother with "Head In The Clouds." Banal and boring!JANA
Title: N/A

reviewText: Guy (Stuart Townshead) loves Mia (Penelope Cruz) & Gilda(Charlize Theron). They love him. They also love each other & they all live together. Gilda is also rich.Sweet.That however, does not a movie make.Guy & Mia are working class with political conscience. Witnessing the Spanish Civil War in newsreels they are determined to participate, to Gilda's dismay. She sees their perfect life disintegrating. She is rich, spoiled & in denial as the world around her is changing. She cuts off all contact with the two people she loves most as they leave for Spain.The war is a life changing experience for Guy & a life ending one for Mia as she dies heroically in defense of her homeland.The story then picks up mid World War II. Guy, now with British military intelligence parachutes into occupied France to help the free French resistance. He of course hooks up with Gilda. She apparently is a collaborator, dating German officers. She is despised by all her neighbors & friends. But she too has changed.This movie has the raw material for an epic but falls short. When you have eye candy like Cruz & Theron it's hard to be taken seriously which is too bad. They both give fine performances. It is a bit long on exposition: how Gilda met Guy, a student at Cambridge & Mia's back story. It's a well traveled gen're: love lost, war, love found again. It is a war movie, however & worth a look.
summary: Paris,  the 1930's & a menage a'  trios.

reviewText: Oscar Winner Charlize Theron (Best Actress, 'Monster'), real-life boyfriend Stuart Townsend, and Penelope Cruz star in "Head in the Clouds", a movie few people know about that is actually really good. It really surprised me how good it was, I didn't even think I'd like it. Anyway, Townsend plays Guy, a young student who falls in love with Gilda Besse (Therone) the day she rushes into his college dorm room. Gilda is a free spirit, who drifts from guy to guy and eventually ends up with Guy. After years apart and finally moving in together, along with a studying nurse Mia (Cruz). Mia and Gilda are movie lesbians basically, you've seen versions of them in "Wild Things" and other movies. Eventually, Mia and Guy leave to fight in the Spanish Civil War much to the dismay of Gilda who doesn't believe in war. Mia and Guy leave Gilda behind and she vows to herself never to see them again. One great scene ensues when Guy returns to France to see Gilda, when he spots her on the street they exchange a glance and she walks away. This scene is wonderful and very poetic. One thing this film should not be confused with is a "war movie". It's not a war movie, it's not even kind of a war movie. "Head in the Clouds" uses war as a plot point, but the movie is really a love story. It's like "The Dreamers" and "The Unbearable Lightness of Being" in which, war is an overtone to the movie. Charlize Theron is glamorous in this movie, she's really in true movie star mode. Stuart Townsend, who also appeared with Theron in "Trapped", is really good as Guy; the lovestruck soldier who is forced to make a lot of life changing decisions. Cruz is in one of her best performance as Mia. I am truly surprised this movie didn't recieve more publicity and better reviews than it did, because (as I've stated several times now) this is a fantastic movie. Seeing Theron naked was a plus too.GRADE: A-

reviewText: "Head in the Clouds" was a good cinematic experience.  It seems to split into 2 films, pre-war & war.  The pre-war part is fun, seeing the affluent party & play.  The war part comes along and each character seems to find deeper reasons for living.  Australian director John Duigan directed one of my favorite little films, "Lawn Dogs" from 1997.  The cinematography here is excellent; costumes are breathtaking; the story is epic, if perhaps just a bit too long.  Charlize Theron is a talented actress & glamorous movie star.  With her Oscar for "Monster" and other excellent performances such as "Sweet November" with Keanu Reeves and the "Italian Job" with Donald Sutherland, we expect a high level of performance which she delivers here.  Socialite playgirl Gilda Besse offers Theron a variety of emotions and displays her promiscuous naughty side, her businesswoman side as she develops a photography business, artist, lover and shows her ultimately capable of duplicity for a good cause.  It is a varied and stunning performance that is riveting.  Irish actor Stuart Townsend who played Dorian Gray in "The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" with Sean Connery does an excellent job as Irish patriot Guy who is torn by his political devotion and his emotional hormonal torrid love affair with Gilda.  Thrown into the mix is dancer Mia played by Penelope Cruz.  Cruz is an interesting actress from Spain who has played opposite Tom Cruise in "Vanilla Sky," in "Gothika" & recently in "Sahara."  As the third person in the love triangle, she performs with a depth & intensity that is full match for Theron & Townsend.  While this film did seem to take a bit too long to conclude, it was an excellent film from a story that developed and characters that changed, reflecting a world that was also in a state of flux and change.  I liked it!  Enjoy!

Other than that, acting was excellent and the movie portrayed the '30s and '40s and events surrounding this time in Europe very well.

reviewText: "Head in the Clouds " aspires to be an epic romance. It is in many ways a classic story of personal relationships set against sweeping social, political, and ideological upheaval. The story takes place over the course of 11 years, starting in 1933, when Guy (Stuart Townsend), a young Irishman studying at Cambridge University, has a brief affair with wealthy, libertine Gilda (Charlize Theron) and ending with the liberation of Paris in 1944. Unable to forget Gilda years later, Guy goes off to join her in Paris, where he finds a rival of sorts for Gilda's love in Mia (Penelope Cruz), a Spanish nursing student and burlesque dancer whom Gilda has befriended. Gilda has no use for wars and politics, believing that a person's obligation is to live life to the fullest, not to throw it away on some cause or other. In contrast, Guy and Mia are idealists and feel compelled to support the Republican forces in Spain as they watch the rise of fascism in Europe.Charlize Theron, Stuart Townsend, and Penelope Cruz certainly make an attractive trio. Their heyday in Paris has lots of atmosphere, and Theron's wardrobe is lovely. But "Head in the Clouds" seems much longer than it is, probably because it is full of extraneous scenes that make it longer than it needed to be and weaken the relationship between Guy and Gilda that is the story's impetus. Guy and Gilda's love is never quite believable, and I can't say exactly why, but it could be a simple lack of "chemistry". Writer and director John Guigan's intention was to make a moving, tragic, epic romance around some of the 20th century's greatest conflicts. In this case, "epic" means too long, and the romance seems contrived. Although it would essentially be asking Guigan to make a different film than he did, I could not help thinking, while watching "Head in the Clouds", that it would have been more interesting to explore the validity of Gilda's and Guy's conflicting personal creeds. Guy is an idealist who believes in a global community, that people can change the world for the better, and that he has an obligation to intervene wherever people are being persecuted. Gilda believes individuals have a responsibility to protect themselves and not squander any bit of life, which frequently means that she exercises "judicious cowardice" in all things political. Since the romance is unconvincing, "Head in the Clouds" might have benefitted from more ideological analysis.The DVD: "The Making of Head in the Clouds" (9 minutes) includes interviews with writer/director John Guigan, production designer Jonathan Lee, and actors Charlize Theron, Stuart Townsend, and Penelope Cruz, in which they speak generally about the story, characters, and the film's style. Subtitles for the film are available in English only.

reviewText: This bittersweet epic love tale encompasses a golden time for three lovers and their friends in the early years before the Spanish Civil War and then World War II. It follows a rich heiress (Charlize Theron) who pretty much just wants to enjoy her privileged lifestyle and though she had many male admirers and lovers she finds herself falling for a man of somewhat lower station (Stuart Townsend), who aspires to fight in the Spanish Civil War and then in the French Resistance. Some might argue he's an idealist whereas she is a realist though the film supports the belief that we live in the same world and therefore need to defend it even if it is another country. Penelope Cruz plays a love interest and friend to Theron, longing to return to her Spanish homelands.There are prominent themes of fate, love, duty and doom. The lovers are definitely torn in their beliefs between love at all expenses and duty to an ideal.As of late I'm finding the WWII stories to be saturating the market but I did find the unattainable love story engaging. Pessimists will find it melodramatic.This picture won a number of Genie Awards. Memorable soundtrack, too. I am surprised this picture wasn't based on a novel.CINEMATOGRAPHY: A minus; STORY/PLOTTING/EDITING: B plus to A minus; CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: A minus to A; EPIC SCOPE/COSTUMES/SETTING: B plus; ROMANTIC TALE FOCUSES: A minus; WHEN WATCHED: early September 2012; OVERALL GRADE: A minus

reviewText: Unlike some other reviewers, I actually found chemistry among these three characters.  I do not think, however, that the typical American audience is used to a film like this.  It is a period piece, set against the backdrop of pre-World War II, which shows the blossoming relationships between a self absorbed socialite (Theron), an Irish brooder (Townsend), and a Spanish idealist (Cruz).  They form an unlikely trio in which Gilda the socialite is the centerpiece.This movie has lots of potential, and it's not the acting that ruins it.  In fact I thought the acting was A+.  The story spent too much time focusing on the trivial and not enough time focusing on the richness that was the era.  I didn't mind the length of the film (2 hours plus), but it could have been filled more with character development and less with extraneous scenes and people.  I would have cared more for the lead characters if I was given more information about them.Still, I watched, partly because I wanted to see what Charlize Theron would do after her fantastic work in Monster, and partly because I had never seen Stuart Townsend in anything before.  His performance was very genuine and appealing I thought.  It's too bad the film didn't quite live up to its potential.

reviewText: Charlize Theron, her real life boyfriend Stuart Townsend, and Penelope Cruz are all nice to look at, and have at times shown considerable tlane in their work, Theron having won as Osca for her role in Monster.But Head In The Clouds is one of those beautifully filmed films starring a beautiful cast that trying to stay beautiful in an increasingly ugly world, particularly Europe in the 1930s. From the Spanish Civil War to World War II, the stories of these three people who share a Paris flat together is supposed to be a sweeping tragedy that shows how world events and fate can conspire to thwart true love.Instead, it shows how silly things can be when you mix hedonism, narcissism, social responsbility, and sheer stupidity. You end up caring less about the characters, andwondering more how much more trouble will they get themselves in. This was a pretty stylish waste of time for everyone involved.
summary: Head In The Clouds Is A Very Appropriate Title For This Movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: Caught this movie on a cable channel and couldn't get it out ofmy mind for days! Chalize Theron dazzles, Penelope Cruz foronce doesn't play for glamour and Stuart Townsend shines as thehero in this 1940's Nazi-era France drama. Theron is a designerwho not only doubles as a "madam" but also as a Nazi spy, Cruzis her lover and Spanish patriot along with Englishman Townsendwho decide they must try to do their part and leave Theronbehind. There is war, there is high drama, there is tendernessand a frightening end...this is a movie in the style of the real1940's; it isn't a edge-of-your-seat film but more of a "sleeper", it's about three people during a turbulent time in history. Good movie for a wet Sunday afternoon!
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Head in the Clouds" is Charlize Theron's during World War II. While her male and female lovers (Stuart Townsend, Penelope Cruz) fret about  fascism in Spain and the collapse of The Third Republic, Charlize lives for the pleasures she savors. As Europe is overtaken by war, Theron adapts to whatever will keep her in cafe society, which in occupied Paris means sleeping with Nazis. Her lovers decamp for Spain to fight Franco and Theron moves in with a kindly torturer. Her English lover returns as a resistance fighter and time runs out for our darling dilettante.Period music, locations, costumes and sets are all lovingly recreated. That can't be said for the script. The actors are beautiful until they start to speak. Cruz is the only one who conveys any depth or conviction. This movie, if you can't tell by now, ends badly for everyone. Crucial information is withheld to provide a surprise ending that fails to deliver. The good intentions of "Head in the Clouds" make its failures more noticeable. You want to like this movie but its surfaces won't let you.
Title: N/A
